story.text: NEW YORK (Reuters Life!) - Getting a blood transfusion during or after heart bypass surgery may raise the risk of dying in the next few months after the operation, new research suggests.Moreover, this may explain in part why women are more likely than men to die after coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), since women more commonly need transfusions than men do.The findings, which appear in the American Heart Journal, suggest that transfusions suppress the immune system, which increases the likelihood of infection and this in turn raises mortality."To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to state that ... transfusions may be the reason why women have a greater post-CABG mortality than men," Dr. Mary A. M. Rogers, from the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, said in a statement.In a study of Michigan Medicare beneficiaries, 88 percent of female CABG patients received a blood transfusion compared with 67 percent of male patients.The infection rate was 15 percent for transfused patients but 5 percent rate among non-transfused patients.Patients who received a blood transfusion were 5.6-times more likely to die within 100 days of undergoing heart bypass surgery than were non-transfused patients, the report indicates.On initial analysis, it looked like female patients were more likely to die than their male counterparts. However, after taking account of who got transfusions and who didn't, there was no longer any significant mortality difference between women and men.
story.title: transfusions blamed for deaths after heart bypass
